Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Analyzing cultural differences about how children make moral judgments under social pressure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent research has found that in the face of conflicting visual evidence, children as young as 4 years old conform to their inaccurate peers. Moreover, Asian American children conform at higher rates than Caucasian American children, suggesting that cultural differences in parenting style might account for some of these differences. The present study will explore how cultural norms impact children's ability to make visual, moral, and social-conventional judgments under social pressure. Understanding why Singaporean preschool children might be sensitive to their peers as a key social reference group can help us to prevent poor social learning and peer pressure issues in primary school. Singapore's unique educational emphasis and societal control over moral responsibility makes it an opportune culture for researchers to examine moral conformity. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Professor Catherine Wan, a noted Asian Social Psychology expert, at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.

Using modified versions of a classic conformity task, the structure of the study will include video clips followed by interviews. During the study, 3-5 year old children will be asked to perform basic perceptual tasks (i.e. determining line length), moral judgment tasks (i.e. determining whether it is acceptable to shove another child), and social-conventional tasks (i.e. determining whether it is acceptable to wear a bathing suit to school). The rate at which children either choose to go with their own judgment or agree with what the inaccurate groups in the videos say will be measured. Surveys will also be distributed to the parents to examine the influence of child's temperament and parenting styles on conformity. Examining how Singaporean children make decisions has larger implications for other collectivist societies and minority groups that share group-oriented tendencies. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The present study explored cultural differences in preschoolers’ ability to make visual, moral and social judgments under group pressure. Understanding preschoolers’ sensitivity to their peers when making these judgments not only broadens our knowledge of early moral and social development, but also can help illuminate how cultural norms of socialization – in particular, ones that value conformity over individualism—impact Asian preschooler’s ability to deal with peer pressure in various situations. Singapore’s unique educational emphasis and societal control over moral responsibility of its citizens made it an opportune culture for researchers to examine young children’s moral conformity to their peers. Examining Singaporean preschooler’s conforming behavior also has larger implications for other collectivist societies and minority groups in the U.S. that share similar group-oriented tendencies.

Ninety-two Singaporean 3- and 5-year-olds participated in this study. Children were asked to perform basic visual judgment tasks (i.e. comparing line length) as well as moral judgment (i.e. determining whether pushing/teasing another child is acceptable or not) and social-convention judgment (i.e. determining whether wearing a bathing suit to school is acceptable or not) tasks both independently and in the presence of inaccurate peer groups. Conformity was measured by children’s agreement with the peer groups who always made visually incorrect and morally/socially erroneous judgments. Mothers also provided information about their children’s personalities, expectations for their children’s behaviors, and their parental control. This data was compared with previously collected data on U.S. children’s responses to the same research tasks.

Results showed that nationality predicted whether or not preschoolers would conform to their peers’ inaccurate visual, moral, and social-convention judgments. Singaporean preschoolers tended to conform to the erroneous majority more than U.S. children on moral judgments. Regardless of nationality, younger children were more likely to conform to their peers’ than older children. There were no significant gender differences in conformity. Singaporean preschoolers that were rated by their parents as high in impulsiveness were associated with higher rates of conformity, but not for U.S. preschoolers. Taken together, these results suggest that preschoolers’ conformity to peers varies by country, child’s age, and child’s temperament. These results are consistent with recent findings that children below age 5 are sensitive to peer pressure when making simple judgments.

This study will inform the fields of child development and moral education by allowing for connections between early moral conformity and peer pressure issues in later childhood (i.e. bullying, poor social assimilation) to be understood more clearly. Findings can also help early childcare educators to understand cultural differences in children’s moral reasoning and better interpret behaviors of children from more collectivist cultures.
